name: Saving Throws
description: All characters and monsters can make saving throws to avoid the full effects of certain magical or special attacks.

categories.name: Categories
categories.description: There are five saving throw categories, used in the following situations:

d.name: Death or Poison
d.description: When targeted by a death ray or exposed to poison.

w.name: Wands
w.description: When targeted by an effect from a magical wand.

p.name: Paralysis or Petrification
p.description: When targeted by an effect that paralyses or turns to stone.

b.name: Breath Attacks
b.description: When targeted by the breath of a dragon (or other monster with a breath attack).

s.name: Spells, Rods, or Staves
s.description: When targeted by a baneful spell or an effect from a magical rod or staff.

whenToRollaSavingThrow.name: When to Roll a Saving Throw
whenToRollaSavingThrow.description: The appropriate saving throw to make and the effects of a success or failure are indicated in the description of the spell, monster attack, or adventure scenario.

rollingaSavingThrow.name: Rolling a Saving Throw
rollingaSavingThrow.description: When affected by a spell or attack form which requires a saving throw, the player or referee must roll 1d20 and compare the result to the appropriate saving throw value.

success.name: Greater or equal
success.description: A result that is greater than or equal to the saving throw value is a success.

falure.name: Lower
falure.description: A result of less than the saving throw value is a failure.

1.name: Damaging effects
1.description: A successful save against an effect that causes damage means that the damage is halved.

2.name: Other effects
2.description: A successful saving throw against an effect that does not cause damage means the effect has been entirely avoided or negated.

failure.name: Failure
failure.description: A failed save against poison is usually fatal.

damage.name: Damage
damage.description: If a poisonous attack also inflicts damage, the damage is not affected by the success or failure of the saving throw.
